title: My Honest Take on the Pear Tallow Balm (Yes, the Beef Fat One)
body:
Okay so I was scrolling on my phone, one beer in, and I saw this thing. A whipped tallow balm. Pear scent. Made from beef fat. For your face. I stopped. My brain did that record-scratch thing. Beef tallow skincare? Like… cooking fat? On my skin? I think I actually said “what” out loud to my empty living room. The fridge was making that noise again, the one that sounds like a distant motorcycle. Anyway. I’ve got this skin. It gets angry in winter. Like, tight, flaky, just generally pissed off. I’ve tried the expensive stuff in the fancy jars. Felt nice going on. Did nothing. So I was curious. And skeptical. Very, very skeptical. But I clicked buy. Because why not. My skin couldn’t get much worse.

It arrived in a little box. I opened it up. Here’s the thing about beef tallow for skin – you hear it and you picture a greasy tub of lard. This wasn’t that. It was in a small glass jar. The stuff inside was white and fluffy. Like if buttercream frosting and whipped cream had a baby. I unscrewed the lid. Sniffed it. Smelled like pear? Or maybe not. Something sweet. But light. Not like candy. More like… you know when you walk past a fruit stand in summer. That’s it. It was subtle. I poked it with my finger. Cold. Weird texture. Not bad weird. Just… unfamiliar. I’m sitting there, looking at this jar of whipped beef fat, thinking “what have I done.”

## How I Started Putting Beef Tallow on My Face

Look. I need to back up. The whole idea sounds insane. I get it. Is tallow good for skin? That was my exact Google search while I sat there with the jar. My cat was judging me from the couch. The logic, from what I read while half-watching a rerun in the background, is kinda simple. Our skin makes oil, right? Sebum. Beef tallow, especially from grass-fed cows, is apparently really close to that. Closer than most plant oils or whatever’s in the lab-made creams. So the idea is it sinks in better. Your skin recognizes it. It’s not sitting on top like a greasy mask. It’s more like… food. For your face. I’m butchering the science. But that’s the gist. It made a weird kind of sense. Like using honey on a cut. Old school.

So I washed my face. Dried it. Took a tiny bit of this pear tallow balm on my fingertip. Rubbed my hands together. It melted immediately. From fluffy to almost nothing. I patted it on my cheeks, forehead, chin. It was cold. Then it was just… gone. No film. No shine. My skin felt… calm. Not moisturized, yet. Just calm. Like it took a deep breath. I didn’t look like I’d rubbed steak on my face. That was the first surprise.

I went to bed. Forgot about it.

## Why This Pear Tallow Balm Actually Works

Woke up the next day. My skin usually feels like parchment in the morning. Tight. That day it didn’t. It just felt like skin. Normal skin. I touched my cheek. Still soft. Not “product” soft. Just… my skin soft. Huh.

I kept using it. Morning and night. Just a little dab. The jar from that Etsy shop lasted forever. The scent is hard to describe. It’s not “PEAR!!” It’s gentle. Sophisticated? That sounds dumb. It’s just nice. Fresh. Not perfume-y. It doesn’t clash with anything. My pillow didn’t smell like a fruit salad. It just smelled like clean laundry and maybe, if you really tried, a little something sweet.

Here’s where the beef tallow skincare benefits got real for me. It was maybe a week in. I have these patches on my elbows. Always dry. Always rough. Like sandpaper. I’d put lotion on them but it never stuck. On a whim, I used a bit of the tallow balm. Just rubbed it in before bed. Two days later I touched my elbow and I didn’t recognize it. It was smooth. Not “just moisturized” smooth. Actually, legitimately smooth. I showed my partner. “Feel this!” They were confused. But they felt it. “Wow,” they said. “What did you do?” I just pointed to the little jar on my nightstand.

That’s the thing. It’s hydrating in a way that’s… quiet. It doesn’t shout. It just does the job. My face stopped feeling tight an hour after washing. The little dry flaky bits around my nose vanished. My knuckles stopped cracking. I started using it on my cuticles. It’s winter. The air is dry. This stuff just… handles it. It’s like it gives my skin what it’s been asking for but not getting from the chemical soups in plastic bottles.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

I’m not a skincare person. I don’t have a routine. I wash my face with whatever soap is in the shower. But this tallow balm became the one thing I did. Consistently. Because it was easy and it worked. No ten-step process. Just clean skin, tiny bit of balm, done.

The results weren’t dramatic in a “wow you look 20 years younger” way. They were practical. My skin barrier felt stronger. Is that a thing? It just felt more resilient. Less reactive. I got a bit of windburn after a cold walk. Slapped some tallow on it. The redness was gone by morning. No sting. Nothing. My sister has eczema on her hands. I told her about it. She was horrified at first. “Beef fat?!” But she tried it. She texted me a week later. “Okay it’s weird but my hands aren’t itching.” That’s the best review I can give. It just works.

I ran out of the first jar last month. I stared at the empty glass. I had a moment. Was I really going to re-order beef fat for my face? Yes. Yes I was. I’m on my second jar now. It sits next to my bed. It’s the only skincare product I’ve ever repurchased.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, honestly. I was the biggest skeptic. But the logic checks out. It’s similar to our skin’s own oils, so it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top. It’s packed with vitamins and good fats. My face has never been happier or less fussy, especially in winter.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about this. My skin can get clogged easy. But no. This stuff melts right in. It’s non-comedogenic, which is a fancy way of saying it shouldn’t clog pores. It hasn’t for me. It just makes my skin feel balanced. Not greasy, not dry.

**What does the pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s light. Fresh. Like a ripe pear but not sugary or fake. It’s not strong. You put it on and the scent is gone in a minute. It just leaves your skin feeling good. No perfume smell hanging around.

So yeah. That’s my experience. Putting beef tallow on my face sounded like the weirdest thing I’d ever do. Now it’s just my normal. My skin is calm. It’s not a miracle cream, but it’s the most effective, simple thing I’ve found. If your skin is being difficult, or dry, or just needs something real to work with… it might be worth getting past the weirdness. I’m glad I did. My elbows are glad too.
